article.description: Barbara Turner scored 19 points as  No. 1 Connecticut dominated Saint Joseph's 87-34.
article.headline: Saint Joseph's shot just 24 percent from the field
article.linkText: Turner turns on the No. 1 Huskies for another win
article.story:
PHILADELPHIA (AP) -- Connecticut shook off a slow start and
showed Geno Auriemma just how well it could play.

Barbara Turner scored 19 points and Diana Taurasi added 18
Sunday, leading No. 1 Connecticut to an 87-34 rout of Saint
Joseph's.

The Huskies (8-0) started 5-for-15 from the floor, missed easy
layups and made a few turnovers early before straightening out
their offense and giving the Hawks (4-3) their worst loss ever.

UConn closed the first half on a 13-2 run -- making 12 of its
final 18 shots -- then made 19 of 28 shots in the second half and
finished 10-for-15 from 3-point range.

"That's the best basketball we played all season," Auriemma
said. "I don't think there's been a 20-minute stretch at any point
in time during the season we've looked as good as we looked during
those 20 minutes."

Turner went 8-for-12 from the floor with nine rebounds and
Taurasi was 8-for-10 with five assists. The Huskies finished 36-61
from the field; Saint Joe's was 11-for-46.

Ann Strother added 14 points for UConn and 10 players scored.

"This was a breakout game," Turner said. "It's kind of
frustrating when you get off to a slow start, but I think the fact
that we stayed with it and made plays was really important. The way
we came out in the second half just justified everything."

Maura McBryan and Elizabeth Mohan each scored seven points for
the Hawks, who are 0-7 against top-ranked teams.

The Huskies had a 29-4 run in the second half, allowing Auriemma
to bench his starters with 8:25 left. This was UConn's 32nd
straight road victory.

"I felt bad in the second half, because as well as we played, I
don't think there was anything Saint Joe's kids could have done
about it," Auriemma said.

The Huskies scored off the opening tip, but McBryan hit a
3-pointer for the only lead for Saint Joseph's. Connecticut had
turnovers on its next two possessions. The Hawks, however, failed
to score both times.

"That was unacceptable. We've got to clean that up," Taurasi
said.

Saint Joseph's made it 29-17 after another McBryan 3, but that
was as close as the Hawks would get. Turner hit a 3-pointer to
start the run, then added a couple of layups right before halftime,
making it 42-19.

"She's a tough matchup for people," Auriemma said.

Saint Joe's lost by 47 points twice before -- to Old Dominion in
1980 and Rutgers in 1981.

"I know the kids know they could have played better, regardless
of what the outcome might be," said Saint Joe's coach Cindy
Griffin. "I don't think we gave it everything that we had today. I
think for 10 minutes we did, but you can't beat anybody playing 10
minutes, especially Connecticut."

The Huskies played their first game at the Palestra since
winning the East Regional in 1991 for their first trip to the Final
Four. Connecticut has been to the Final Four six times since,
winning four national championships. One of those titles, in 2000,
was in Philadelphia.

Auriemma is from Philadelphia and was an assistant for Saint
Joe's in 1979.

"The minute we got here, it was 'Philly this and Philly that,'"
Taurasi said.

Then he left with a happy homecoming.
